Award.AwardTitle: Geometric Combinatorics and Discrete Morse Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Discrete geometry deals with objects that have corners and ridges, such as cubes or surfaces sewn out of triangles. Objects of this type are called polytopal complexes and provide a general approach to the study of other fields of mathematics, such as differential geometry and algebraic topology. The main advantage of discretizing is the possibility to leverage computational tools. Simple questions on the structure of polytopes, such as the Hirsch conjecture, have foundational importance in optimization. Meanwhile discrete Morse theory, a reduction tool to simplify a given polytopal complex, is employed both in pure mathematics and in big data analysis, to understand high-dimensional shapes. The project builds on these tools and expands their application. Further tools arise from the study of networks, which are polytopal complexes of dimension one. A plan is to integrate in this line of work new random models, with the goal of revealing fundamental properties of intersection patterns of algebraic varieties.

Enumerative aspects on the number of polytopes and spheres with given number of facets have importance beyond pure mathematics, in Regge calculus and simplicial quantum gravity. Techniques from metric geometry can provide desired exponential upper bounds. Another problem with importance in applied mathematics is the polynomial Hirsch conjecture, which was recently proven with metric methods for flag polytopes. Techniques ranging from knot theory to differential and hyperbolic geometry may be applied to better understand obstructions and constructions in Discrete Morse Theory, thereby revealing when and how we can simplify a given shape. A new perspective in this project is to connect discrete Morse theory with the notion of embeddability. A further goal is to lift the classical theory of polytope graphs (for example Balinski's theorem or the Hirsch conjecture) into a more general theory of intersection patterns of algebraic varieties, where algebraic tools such as liaison theory and local cohomology can be employed. Integrating this theory with the study of random simplicial complexes may provide some new random models in commutative algebra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's research is in geometric combinatorics. It aims at approaching long-standing open problems in differential, convex, and algebraic geometry, with the help of combinatorial, algorithmic, and probabilistic tools. The PI's work reflects the interdisciplinary spirit of these fields and thrives on developing new interactions.

Polytopes exist in nature, from crystals to honeycombs, and have been studied since the beginning of mankind. Their study has boomed in the last decades, with growing connections to many areas of mathematics and computer science. Polytopes serve as domain for linear optimization; they serve as atoms to discretize surfaces and varieties; they serve as models for  multi-agent interactions. (The simplest interactions involve only two agents and can be modeled using polytopal complexes of dimension one, also known as `graphs' or `networks', but more complex interactions require higher dimensions). 

The main advantage of viewing the world through the lens of polytopes is the activation of inductive and computational tools. This is important beyond pure mathematics; for example, the Hirsch conjecture (which Adiprasito and the PI proved for flag polytopes) has foundational importance in convex optimization. Meanwhile discrete Morse theory, a reduction tool to faithfully simplify a given shape, is employed to understand high-dimensional shapes arising from big data. A third application is given by discrete quantum gravity, a discrete model in physics; during the last funding period, the PI disproved the conjecture by Mogami that all triangulated balls arise from a tree of tetrahedra. The Mogami conjecture would have implied a much desired convergence for the so-called "dynamical triangulations" model in physics. The PI's work appeared in Nuclear Physics B. 

The PI regularly participates to conferences, summer schools and seminars in America and Europe, serves as referee and organizer, and runs a very active research seminar at U Miami together with his mentor, Michelle Wachs.  The seminar has a particular attention on young speakers and speakers from underrepresented groups, and is often occasion for collaborations even beyond the combinatorics community. For example, the two-week visit by Michela Di Marca and her advisor Matteo Varbaro, who both gave talks at U Miami, has resulted in a joint paper in algebraic geometry, on intersection patterns of arrangements of lines and curves. Objects like the 27 lines on a smooth cubic in P3 are very classical in algebraic geometry, and it was surprising to discover something new about them. The fact that each of the 27 lines meets exactly 10 of the others, has a deeper explanation: If a line arrangement is a complete intersection of two surfaces of P3, and at least one of the surfaces is smooth, then every line of the arrangement  meets the same number of other lines. This number is precisely the sum of the surface degrees, minus two.

Much progress remains to be done in all areas mentioned above. This will be the focus of future analogous projects.
